text: so we have
really two categories of medications um
those that target at the level of the
tumor itself
uh in order to reduce growth hormone
secretion and in
some cases shrink the tumor remnant that
is present
we also have therapies that are more
targeted at decreasing the insulin-like
growth factor or igf-1 production from
the liver
in response to that growth hormone
secretion from the tumor
so really at two different levels and
these can be used as
single or monotherapies and in some
cases it is necessary to use
combinations
of these medications to control growth
hormone igf-1 levels
and tumor growth at the level of the
tumor
we think about somatostatin receptor
ligands
these are medications that bind to a
receptor on the surface of the tumor
they turn down growth hormone production
uh they can
slow growth tumor growth and sometimes
even lead to cell death
and so these are um very important
medications for use
for patients with acromegaly they
include some of
the older injectables sandostatin lar
and lanreatide autogel are both
intermittent intramuscular or deep
subcutaneous injections respectively
that patients will have an injection
every four weeks and in some cases every
six to eight weeks depending on the
control of their
of their disease um a newer uh
medication in the landscape in the last
decade
is passariotide lar it is a similar
somatostatin receptor ligand although it
is
uh more activity in many of these tumors
and can be used for
more aggressive or um large tumors that
are not as responsive to actual tidal
and rheotide
um and then and then we now have the new
kid on the block which is
oral octreotide capsules so we
understand how
octreotide works to treat growth hormone
tumors and so now
uh there is an oral formulation so
instead of a monthly injection
or um or every six weeks or every eight
weeks patients
now have a choice to do the oral
octreotide capsules which would
be twice daily and so it just really
depends on
the patient's preference their
own personal characteristics in terms of
the
tumor as to whether which of those
therapies would be appropriate for them
with regard to a therapy that targets at
the level of the liver
we have pigvisimont which inhibits the
production
of insulin like growth factor from the
liver in response to growth hormone
so it's not really going to control the
tumor
growth per se or shrink the tumor but it
does lead to lower igf-1 and can really
alleviate symptoms
in many patients because of that hormone
